posts.cooked: After seeing requests in the community for more splineX-S compatible products and the ability to manufacture splines in-house more easily, I investigated the feasibility of manufacturing a custom broach. Quotes from overseas manufacturers indicate prices ranging from $250 to $350 per piece, with a minimum order quantity of 1. I aim to assess interest from the broader FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) community for such a product to estimate potential volumes. My current pricing target, including shipping, is $325 to $350. If this concept appeals to you or you have feedback or ideas, please consider replying below.

link_counts.title: Kraken X60 to Sport Gearbox adapter

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
FRC 453 is considering more details. We love our 1/2-inch hex and 3/8-inch hex broches from AndyMark. They're worth the price due to their frequent use.  

My main issue is the broach length—the current 1/2-inch one is too long for our "large" arbor press, forcing the use of 2x4 props and placing stock on the press anvil. It's quite inconvenient. A 2-inch reduction would solve the problem.  

This broach is 11 7/8 inches long, making a shorter option like the 3/8-inch hex broach (8.5 inches) preferable for our needs. However, concerns about manufacturing requirements and whether a shorter broach for a larger object is feasible remain unanswered.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: I also don’t know enough about broach manufacturing to know if you need that length to get a good cut and more blades to help ease the press. It might not be possible to have a short broach for a large diameter object. This is basically the problem with broaches. Each tooth takes just a little bit of material. Keyway broaches partly solve the length problem by using shims after one pass (though they do tend to be longer as the broach gets bigger). Hex broaches don’t have that option available.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Very important, indeed. Does that apply to splines still?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Never seen a spline broach… but I would find it reasonable for it to apply to them as well.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
spline-broach-tools image source: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/optimized/3X/2/f/2fe90dc835315d427b45b9f54b90716136459e1b_2_450x1000.jpeg 2x

This tool features multiple teeth requiring individual stepped blades. Research indicates significant lengths involved, suggesting compression isn't feasible.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: I’ve seen suggestions to bore a hole in the arbor press ram with a lathe to simplify the process. For instance, one person shared that there was nearly 1.75 inches of the broach in the arbor, and they were willing to assist, though shipping costs might exceed local expenses.
Could you split it across two broaches? I’ve seen this on very large taps, but I’m not a machinist and we don’t use any broaches so I’m not really sure.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: 1918 would definitely be in for a broach.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: You could, but it would be more expensive and someone could use the wrong one first and for sure break something. I would still suggest the old way of drillig out the arbor and reming to the end size, say 3 or 4 inches deep, then drilling 2 or 3 inches after that to give your broach teeth plenty of clearance.

posts.name: Hikel team 319
posts.cooked: FRC 319 would be interested in a splineXS profiled broach.

posts.name: Scott Brondel
posts.cooked: FRC 6377 would be interested

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: A regular broach and not a rotary broach?

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: I assume we are talking a broach for the Kraken shafts?

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: 271 would be interested in a SplineXS broach.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: yes, splineXS is the kraken shaft profile

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: Should be a fairly short broach, as those are pretty small teeth—there’s not much to remove.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Small diameter but with more and smaller teeth than a typical gear profile. My worry is whether we will need it to be longer to achieve precise cuts that remove very small amounts from each level. It is not a lot of material, but rather how accurate the cuts are on all of the blades over time. Lots of fine small teeth can be more easily damaged if you take away too much at once.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: OMG, I’m interested too! The lack of a broach is the most annoying thing in the Kraken ecosystem. The broach is likely to be in the 5" department; that’s what a 1/16" keyway broach is. If we specified that the maximum cut length was 1" it could get shorter.

Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text: ---

I’ve received several quotes recently, each with varying pricing and specifications. By the end of this week, I anticipate having them narrowed down and finalized. My goal is to either meet or exceed the $325 price target, aiming to maintain a similar size to the AM 3/8 hex broch.

Preserved the original meaning while ensuring proper grammar and punctuation. 4. Maintained consistency in terminology ("broch" instead of "broach"). This version effectively communicates the essential information with minimal alterations.
